ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Theory and practicality of different renewable energy methods. Formulas and calculations to support these.
I got a great background on renewable energy, including the economics and physics behind renewable energy technologies.
Learned a lot about the scientific/mathematical principles underlying renewable energy sources.
I learned about the technical and economic advantages and disadvantages of different forms of renewable energy.
Overview of renewable energy source and their role in world energy systems

I learned about many different facets of the way renewable energy is used (primarily in the US but also around the world).  We hit on each type of renewable energy, spending the most time on hydropower, wind, and solar but also covering bioenergy, nuclear, geothermal, and energy storage.  The course started out with a nice introduction to energy including emissions, economics, how the US grid works, ISO/bidding system, and key components of the grid such as transformers.  During each renewable energy topic, discussions shifted more to scientific themes and technology, while still covering environmental benefits and challenges, pricing, policy, and plant examples.  Great intro to a topic everyone should know about.
Apart from the insights into the different renewable energy technologies, I also enjoyed learning about the US energy grid and markets

Renewable energy technology, some of the physics behind it (hydro, wind, solar, a few others)

Interesting looks into the economics, electricity markets etc

I learned how to think about various renewable energy sources and the factors that drive their production. I learned about the science behind how they create electricity, how that electricity is transmitted, upon numerous other things. If you are interested in renewable energy, I highly recommend this course.

I learned about the major types of renewable energy technologies: hydropower, geothermal, CSP, PV solar, biofuels, nuclear, tidal/wave. I also learned about how the basics of the energy grid/market in the US. In the final portion of class, I learned about batter storage and the future of energy. I learned about the different energy-related resources out there like EIA, IEA, BP Statistical Review, etc.
Learned a lot about the scientific principles and theories behind energy, and power generation - most specifically solar, hydropower, wind, and tidal.
I learned about renewable energy technology, policy, and markets.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the course was wonderful, and I wouldn't change it.

Strengths: Well-arranged for learning, the slides were very thorough and made it easy to go back and study for exams. Content was also interesting and provided a good mix of mathematical elements and real-world topics.
Weaknesses: The material is quite dense and can be somewhat boring at times
interesting material, reasonable grading/evaluation requirements

Strengths: Nice overview and we covered basically every form of renewable energy.  Loved the interdisciplinary nature of this course.  Very accessible even for students without a STEM background.  Great professor who cared about the students and has done some amazing work in his field.  The study sessions were very helpful to me and you can get to know the professor if you attend.  I also appreciated Professor Smith's guest lectures.
Weaknesses: Some of the information on slides came from 2016-2017, which would be fine, except this field is changing so rapidly that some more current info may have been helpful. Also, I thought the final was significantly more difficult than the midterm and I felt like there were some concepts we didn't cover in class.
More explanations about qualitative features that affect performance of different hydro
This course is very practical and interesting. While I wish it was more geared towards finance and business applications, that's my personal bias and not intrinsic to the course. It was wonderful.
Strengths: interesting content, extremely organized, flexible instructor, fair amount of work. Weaknesses: no field trips this year due to covid

Weaknesses: lecture slides were inundated, however some were unnecessary. ~60-70 slide of lecture per class is hard to follow live because of sheer volume. Extremely different expectations and teaching focuses by two instructors made some aspects of the course challenging like on psets. 
Strengths: course was extremely informative and reviewed a lot about solar and wind. I enjoyed Professor Oristaglios constant attempts at showing theory in the real world by narrating how real plants operate. Course review packets and answer guides were great. Midterm review guide was even well-organized and impressive. Overall, grading was extremely fair and I deeply enjoyed the course.

This class was very informative and I enjoyed the mix of energy topics we covered, and especially the "energy tourism" slides. However, I thought sometimes the questions on the problem sets were subjective, or not covered in the slides, and very difficult to answer without attending office hours.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Recorded/asynchronous lectures worked really well for me.
I thought the course was great!
lectures were fine, prof. was accomodating
Study sessions were helpful.  I think if the professor asked people to turn on their cameras at the start of class, many would.
Having lecture slides posted to the Canvas site was very helpful for studying the material
The flexibility of this course was fantastic. Given the complicated circumstances of COVID-19, Professor Oristaglio was amazing at ensuring everyone had the best opportunity to learn.
The recorded lectures and study sessions were successful. Also, it was great being able to have a separate midterm exam time because it fit my time zone better.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, the lectures are engaging and entertaining and you can actually learn practical knowledge about renewable systems.
I would highly recommend this as a fun course to take to get a great background for renewable energy.
Yes, I would if you're interested in going beyond the surface level in renewable energy. I found this course quite a good intro
Yes, great course
yeah, interesting, important material, no need for non stem people to be scared

100%-- without any hesitation.  There is something in this course for everyone.  Amazing professor, great content, not too much work because there were only five problem sets.  Lots of helpful study materials for the midterm and final provided by the professor.  I know this course will be even better in the future when students can go on field trips to various energy sites.

As an engineering major, I thought this class complemented my other core courses really well. Although it was less math intensive than my engineering courses, I was able to use what I learned in this class in my projects for those classes.
Absolutely, great overview of world energy and super informative. Calculation heavy, but not overly challenging.
Yeah, if you are interested in energy at all, or want a light physics class
Yes! Professor Oristaglio is very cool, and a great professor, and the material you learn is awesome
Absolutely, this course was fascinating and well taught.

Yes! If you want to learn more about renewable energy in both a quantitative and qualitative way then take this course! Professor Oristaglio is very nice and understanding. He is super knowledgeable about the field as well. Professor Smith guest lectured a few times and they were interesting as well--though he tends to be a little more quantitative.

I recommend this course to anyone working in the energy sector post-graduation and for non-STEM majors looking to work in climate change and energy polic because limitations and advantages in different energy technology is what create frictional forces.

I would recommend this course to another student. Now, I feel a deeper connection to news I read about energy and in addition to learning new information, I have also gained curiosity/enthusiasm towards the subject of renewable energy.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: live virtual lecture, which was recored to allow for asynchronous learning
none
Live virtual lecture with a live virtual study/office hours session each week.
Reading the lecture slide notes
Searching through slides, solving pset questions with a friend to learn
I mainly watched recorded lecture and reviewed slides uploaded to Canvas.
office hours, pset/exam study session
